bibl.title: Dispatch from L de R. du Verge to J.C. Bancroft Davis
Despatches from United States consuls in St. Paul de Loanda, 1854-1893

revisionDesc.change: Creation of individual xml file, transcription and initial encoding.

div1.dateline: United States Consulate. St. Paul de Loauda Nov. 12 1889.
div1.note: Hon: John Davis Att. Secty. of State Washington D. C.
div1.p:
Sir I have the honor to state that by report received from the Consular agent at Mossamedes that the Am. Whaling Aks. "Hercules" Capt. J. Mac Lewis and "Million" Capt. J. B. Bolter were at that fort during the month of October, also that the Milton rau on shore ha, but got off alright. Mossamedes was infected deso with small pox. The report from Benguela is only n entraising that several of the Am: Missouri from Balinbu were at Beugck buying some goods to Boston in the interior. The Consul agent as Amlry informs me of the arrival of Mr. Baxter An Am Missionary from Gabon who cam e there by reason of the ill health: beside writing the following by: "Am: Trading vessels may be said to have ceased running to this part of the coast altogether with their usual cargo such as lumber, tobacco, cam Far jaj. But there is another important branch of our trade and I have no double whatever if the matter is properly lacked intro, it might eventually lead to the opening
up of an extensive commerce. I mean the manufacture of common ordinary cloths suitable for this trade, suck as greys and stripped Domestics, why cannot the Americans Mills compete with the Manchester, and not the Cotton ready to their hands. Some fear years ago, they did compete successfully with Manchester; actually exporting Am: made greys to Manchester for sale! I am at a loss to know why this was never encouraged unless the Manchester knew cut their prices of one that it discouraged the America manufacturer from preserving. Should you deem my idea of any value, I shall be glad to fosoraid zace samples of good, indicated, and would feel desirous of knowing of what price, in length currency they could the delivered to Liverpool for Bysmeut; or brought and dried from the U.S."
I have the honor to Sir. Your obedient servant L. de R. du Verge le Consul.
N.o 29 Mr. Scarilau Consulate of the United States of America at St. Paul de Laouda W. C. A.
Ls de R. du Verge to State Department Washington D. C.
Incloses. Acknowledgment of the same and trade on Petroleum.
